text: I actually think the first step in a good positioning exercise is to really understand what do we have to position against? So put another way, it's like saying, what do I have to beat in order to win a deal? So in positioning work we call this competitive alternatives. Now, how people mess up this first step is, I say competitive alternatives and they think competition. So things that look exactly like me. But in B2B we kind of have two sets of competitors.
speaker: April Dunford
context: Lenny asks April what the first step is for a PM or founder ready to figure out their product's positioning. April explains that before you can position your product, you need to understand what you're competing against - not just direct competitors, but also the status quo (what customers are currently doing to solve the problem). She emphasizes that many companies lose deals to 'no decision' because they fail to position effectively against existing solutions like spreadsheets or manual processes.
text_ko: 제가 생각하기에 좋은 포지셔닝 작업(positioning exercise)의 첫 번째 단계는 우리가 무엇을 상대해서 포지셔닝해야 하는지를 정말로 이해하는 거예요. 다시 말하면, 거래를 따내기 위해 무엇을 이겨야 하는지, 누구를 이겨야 하는지를 묻는 거죠. 포지셔닝 작업에서는 이를 경쟁 대안(competitive alternatives)이라고 부릅니다. 그런데 사람들이 이 첫 단계를 흔히 잘못 이해하는 건, 제가 '경쟁 대안'이라고 하면 곧장 '경쟁자'—나와 똑같이 보이는 것들—만 떠올린다는 점이에요. 하지만 B2B에서는 사실 경쟁자가 두 가지 종류로 나뉘어요.
text_zh: 我觉得要做好定位(positioning)，第一步其实是要搞清楚我们要对抗什么。换句话说，就是我要打败谁才能拿下这个单子？在定位工作中，我们叫这个"竞争替代方案(competitive alternatives)"。很多人在第一步就搞错了，我一说竞争替代方案，他们就想到竞争对手，就是那些跟我们长得一模一样的公司。但是在B2B里面，其实我们面对两类竞争对手。
text_es: La verdad es que creo que el primer paso en un buen ejercicio de posicionamiento es entender realmente contra qué nos tenemos que posicionar. O sea, dicho de otra manera, es como preguntarse: ¿qué tengo que superar para cerrar un negocio? En el trabajo de posicionamiento a esto le llamamos alternativas competitivas (competitive alternatives). Ahora, donde la gente se equivoca en este primer paso es que digo alternativas competitivas y piensan en competencia directa. O sea, cosas que se parecen exactamente a lo mío. Pero en B2B como que tenemos dos tipos de competidores.
key_sentence: Understand what to position against, called competitive alternatives.

text: So a lot of people look at tracking data as how do I track my OKR? How do I know if I'm going up or down? But they don't use it to track or identify insights. So I will use the example of using Twitter for, "News" when in reality they're actually using Twitter for entertainment. Do not treat metric gathering as entertainment. It's not there for you to be like, oh, that's interesting, how novel, and then not act on it.
speaker: Crystal Widjaja
context: Lenny asks Crystal about her popular post on why most analytics efforts fail and what teams can do to avoid this. Crystal explains that companies often treat data tracking like entertainment rather than actionable intelligence. She uses the analogy of people claiming they use Twitter for news when they're actually using it for entertainment - similarly, teams look at metrics and find them 'interesting' but don't change their behavior based on the insights.
text_ko: 많은 분들이 데이터 추적(tracking data)을 '내 OKR(목표와 핵심 결과)은 어떻게 추적하지? 오르고 있나 내리고 있나?'를 확인하는 용도로만 봐요. 그런데 그걸로 인사이트(insights)를 찾아내거나 식별하는 데는 잘 안 써요. 예를 들어 트위터(Twitter)를 '뉴스'로 쓴다고 생각하지만 사실은 엔터테인먼트(entertainment)로 쓰고 있는 경우가 많습니다. 지표(metric) 수집을 그저 엔터테인먼트(entertainment)처럼 취급하지 마세요. '아, 재밌네, 신기하네' 하고 끝내고 아무 행동도 하지 않는 용도가 아니에요.
text_zh: 很多人看跟踪数据就是为了看自己的OKR(目标与关键结果)怎么样，是在上升还是下降，但他们不会用这些数据去发现洞察。就像很多人说自己上Twitter是为了"看新闻"，实际上就是在娱乐。千万别把收集指标当娱乐，不是让你看了说"哦，挺有意思的，挺新鲜"，然后就没下文了。
text_es: Entonces mucha gente ve los datos de seguimiento como "¿cómo hago tracking de mis OKRs? ¿Cómo sé si voy para arriba o para abajo?" Pero no los usan para identificar insights o sacar conclusiones reales. Te pongo el ejemplo de usar Twitter para "noticias" cuando en realidad lo estás usando para entretenerte. No trates la recopilación de métricas como entretenimiento. No está ahí para que digas "ay, qué interesante, qué curioso" y después no hagas nada al respecto.
key_sentence: Do not treat metric gathering as entertainment; act on insights.

text: But looking back, I think it probably took me about seven or eight years until I became a little bit more comfortable with that. After seven or eight years I could look back, I could see all of the things that I got to work on, I could see all the ways that I had grown and learned in that experience. And something clicked for me where I realized it's kind of two sides of the same coin.
speaker: Julie Zhou
context: Lenny asks Julie about her rapid rise from designer to VP of design at Facebook and what advice she has for early career professionals. Julie reflects on how she felt like an imposter for seven to eight years at Facebook, constantly questioning whether she deserved her position. She explains that over time she realized that feeling uncomfortable and unprepared often coincides with the fastest periods of career growth - it's two sides of the same coin.
vocabulary_highlights: two sides of the same coin
text_ko: 돌이켜보면, 그게 조금 편해지기까지 아마 7~8년 정도 걸린 것 같아요. 7~8년쯤 지나서야 제가 해온 일들을 돌아볼 수 있었고, 그 경험을 통해 얼마나 성장하고 배웠는지도 보이기 시작했어요. 그러다 어느 순간 모든 게 딱 맞춰지면서 결국 그건 같은 동전의 양면이라는 걸 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 不过回头看，我觉得大概花了七八年时间吧，才对这件事稍微适应一些。七八年之后回过头来看，我能看到自己参与过的所有那些项目，也能看到自己在这个过程中各种各样的成长和收获。然后突然就开窍了，意识到这其实是一个硬币的两面。
text_es: Pero mirándolo ahora, creo que me tomó como siete u ocho años hasta que me empecé a sentir más cómodo con eso. Después de esos siete u ocho años pude ver hacia atrás, pude ver todas las cosas en las que había trabajado, todas las formas en las que había crecido y aprendido en esa experiencia. Y ahí fue cuando me cayó el veinte de que en realidad son dos caras de la misma moneda.
key_sentence: After years, I realized it's two sides of the same coin.

text: I have an interview question I ask, it's a very simple question and it's a coded Eigenquestions test. And the question is, a group of scientists have invented a teleportation device. They've hired you, Lenny, to be they're sort of business counterpart, bring this to market, product [inaudible] this question actually worked well for [inaudible]. But say, you could be the product manager for this thing, bring it to market. What do you do?
speaker: Shishir Mehrotra
context: Lenny asks Shishir about his interview techniques and frameworks for evaluating talent. Shishir describes his favorite interview question which tests a candidate's ability to identify 'eigenquestions' - the most important questions that unlock the core understanding needed to make decisions. He gives candidates a hypothetical scenario about commercializing a teleportation device, then limits them to asking only two questions before creating a business plan.
text_ko: 제가 면접에서 자주 묻는 질문이 하나 있어요. 아주 단순한 질문인데 코드화된 Eigenquestions 테스트(Eigenquestions test)에요. 질문은 이래요. 과학자 그룹이 순간이동 장치(teleportation device)를 발명했어요. 그리고 레니(Lenny)를 비즈니스 쪽 파트너로 고용해서 이걸 시장에 내놓으라고 했다고 해요. 제품 관리자(product manager)가 돼서 이걸 시장에 출시한다면, 당신은 어떻게 하시겠어요?
text_zh: 我有个面试问题，很简单的一个问题，其实是个隐性特征测试(coded Eigenquestions test)。问题是这样的：有一群科学家发明了一个传送装置，他们雇你来做商业合作伙伴，负责把这个产品推向市场。假设你就是这个产品的产品经理，要把它推向市场，你会怎么做？
text_es: Tengo una pregunta que siempre hago en entrevistas, es muy sencilla y en realidad es una prueba codificada de Eigenquestions. La pregunta es así: imagínate que un grupo de científicos ha inventado un dispositivo de teletransportación. Te han contratado a ti, Lenny, para ser como su contraparte de negocios, para llevar esto al mercado, ser el product manager... esta pregunta en realidad me ha funcionado muy bien. Pero digamos, tú podrías ser el product manager de esto, llevarlo al mercado. ¿Qué harías?
key_sentence: What do you do to bring this teleportation device to market?

text: There are so many mistakes that humans make and we can call them biases, heuristics, our team uses psychologies. What are the psychologies that drive us? And so to tackle this, our team basically has created a model of behavior change we call the three Bs. And this summarizes the most important psychologies that drive user that are important to the product managers and the marketers.
speaker: Kristen Berman
context: Lenny asks Kristen about using behavioral science to improve products. Kristen introduces her team's framework called the 'three Bs' for understanding behavioral change. This model summarizes the key psychological drivers that influence user behavior and is designed specifically for product managers and marketers. The framework has been implemented at major companies like Google, Microsoft, and LinkedIn to help teams systematically apply behavioral science principles.
text_ko: 사람들이 저지르는 실수들이 정말 많은데, 우리는 그걸 편향(biases)이나 휴리스틱(heuristics)이라고도 하고, 우리 팀은 보통 심리(psychologies)라는 표현을 써요. 그럼 도대체 우리를 움직이는 심리들은 뭘까요? 그래서 이를 해결하려고 우리 팀은 행동 변화 모델(model of behavior change)을 만들었고, 그걸 세 가지 B(Three Bs)라고 불러요. 이 모델은 제품 관리자와 마케터에게 중요한, 사용자를 움직이는 핵심 심리들을 요약한 거예요.
text_zh: 人类会犯很多错误，我们可以叫它们偏见、启发式思维，我们团队叫它们心理因素。到底是什么心理因素在驱动我们呢？为了解决这个问题，我们团队基本上创建了一个行为改变模型，我们叫它"三个B"。这个模型总结了驱动用户的最重要的心理因素，对产品经理和市场营销人员来说特别重要。
text_es: Hay muchísimos errores que cometemos los humanos y los podemos llamar sesgos, heurísticas, nuestro equipo usa el término "psicologías". ¿Cuáles son las psicologías que nos impulsan? Y para abordar esto, nuestro equipo básicamente creó un modelo de cambio de comportamiento que llamamos las tres Bs. Y esto resume las psicologías más importantes que impulsan al usuario y que son clave para los product managers y los de marketing.
key_sentence: Our team created a model of behavior change called the three Bs.

text: I think every single company has to first focus on being product led and retention, period. The only way that you will ever have any chance of acquisition being product led is if you nail your product led retention. Let me break it down. Retention falls into two main KPIs, which is activation and then engagement.
speaker: Elena Verna
context: Lenny discusses B2B growth strategies with Elena, who is head of growth at Amplitude and considered one of the top experts in B2B growth. Elena explains her fundamental principle that companies must master product-led retention before attempting product-led acquisition. She breaks down retention into activation and engagement, arguing that without habitual user engagement, there's no foundation for users to refer others or create content that attracts new users.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 모든 회사가 먼저 제품 주도(product-led)와 고객 유지(retention)에 집중해야 해요. 그게 핵심이에요. 제품 주도(product-led)로 고객 획득(acquisition)을 하려면 제품 주도형 유지(product-led retention)를 확실히 잡아야 해요. 좀 더 풀어 설명할게요. 유지(retention)는 두 가지 핵심 성과 지표(KPI)로 나뉘는데, 하나는 활성화(activation), 다른 하나는 참여(engagement)이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得每家公司都必须先专注于产品驱动(product led)和留存，没得商量。只有你把产品驱动的留存做到位了，你的获客(acquisition)才有可能也做到产品驱动。我给你拆解一下。留存主要看两个关键指标(KPI)，一个是激活(activation)，另一个是用户参与度(engagement)。
text_es: Mira, yo creo que todas las empresas, sin excepción, tienen que enfocarse primero en ser product led y en la retención, punto. La única manera de que tengas alguna posibilidad de que tu adquisición sea product led es si claves completamente tu retención product led. Te lo explico mejor. La retención se divide en dos KPIs principales: la activación y después el engagement.
key_sentence: Focus on being product led and nail your product led retention.

text: All your tasks are not created equal. There are actually three type of tasks that you end up doing in such a role. So there are L tasks, which are leverage tasks. And the L tasks are such that when you put in a certain amount of effort, you get 10X or 100X in return in terms of impact. So those are L tasks, leverage tasks.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny asks Shreyas about productivity frameworks for product managers. Shreyas introduces his LNO framework, which he developed after experiencing overwhelming stress early in his Google career. He explains that not all tasks provide equal return on investment - L tasks (leverage) give 10X or 100X impact, N tasks (neutral) give roughly 1:1 return, and O tasks (overhead) give less return than the effort invested. The key insight is that most people treat all tasks the same way, leading to burnout and inefficiency.
text_ko: 모든 업무가 똑같이 만들어진 건 아니에요. 사실 그런 역할에서는 하게 되는 업무가 세 가지 유형으로 나뉘어요. 그중 하나가 L 작업(L tasks), 즉 레버리지 작업(leverage tasks)인데요. 이런 L 작업은 일정한 노력을 들이면 영향력이 10배(10X)나 100배(100X)로 돌아오는 업무예요.
text_zh: 你的所有任务其实是不一样的。在这种职位上，你做的任务实际上分三种类型。有一种叫L类任务，就是杠杆任务(leverage tasks)。这种L类任务的特点就是，你投入一定的精力，能获得10倍甚至100倍的回报和影响力。这就是L类任务，杠杆任务(leverage tasks)。
text_es: No todas las tareas son iguales. En realidad hay tres tipos de tareas que acabas haciendo en este tipo de rol. Están las tareas L, que son las tareas de apalancamiento (leverage tasks). Y las tareas L son aquellas donde cuando pones cierto esfuerzo, obtienes 10 veces o 100 veces más de retorno en términos de impacto. Esas son las tareas L, las tareas de apalancamiento (leverage tasks).
key_sentence: Tasks are not created equal; leverage tasks yield 10X or 100X in return.
